creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture; formerly given to the Center by Elizabeth and Willard Clark
description: tall, wide, gnarled pine tree with several branches angled downward; small rock to L of tree with small twisting sapling; inscription 2nd screen from L
markings: poem UR red seal: 師在我 {shi zai ga}; poem LL red seals: 福田世耕 {Fukuda Seikō} [Fukuda Seikō #6], 静處 {seisho} [seisho #6]
object_name: Six-panel folding screen, one of a pair
signed: 壬申秋日於蕭山軒　南海一布衣古人詩畫 {mizunoe-saru shūjitsu oite Shōsanken Nankai-ichi hōi Kojin shiga} (An autumn day in 1932 at Lonely Mountain House, poetry and painting by One-of-the-Southern-Sea in Plain-Clothes Kojin) right
text:
置酒高堂且論文　
梅花爲我吐清芬
We set out wine in the high hall and then converse of letters;
Plum blossoms for us spit forth their pure blossoms.

Bamboo and pines were the principal subjects in Kodōjin’s folding screens from the 1930s. In October 1932, he painted this pair of Old Pines that illustrates two gnarled trees bent toward each other. It is quite possible that this was a commission, but unfortunately no records have survived.
title: Old Pines
